div.p: It's easy just to hear the cost savings part of this but I'm looking at my notes from the
remarks and I'm seeing 'User needs first and foremost...', 'How does this make the user
experience better?', 'What is the user need? The most important question for any government
serviceâ€¦'. That's what those of us in the rest of the
world found so inspiring about the Government Digital Strategy. It's really as if for the
first time, Government is doing the thing that is so revolutionary out in Silicon Valley,
which is you're building these lightweight applications and if people don't like them,
if people don't use them, they fail. And that revolution is why we have seen such rapid
change and such rapid development. There has really become almost a cult of user
centred design which has driven innovation forward. And to see that being brought to
government, where we're saying 'wait a minute, we have a customer here, we have to satisfy
that customer'. And the customer is not the government, the customer is the citizen. That
is a revolution. And that's the revolution that we see here.
When all of us who were working in open government saw the UK Government Digital Strategy we
were like 'this is the new bible for anyone working in Government'. This is the document
to study. Everybody around the world should be following this. If we can apply that as
our scripture for government best practices at every level around the world I think we'll
be doing a fantastic service because we need to get away from this notion that government
and the people are odds. And when you build systems where the interfaces between government
and citizens are - to use Jens's words - simple, beautiful and easy to use, you really transform
the very notion of government. I've been using a wonderful quote that we
discovered recently from Abraham Lincoln where he said "the job of government is to
do the things that the people cannot easily or at all do by themselves". And we have to
remember that Government is in fact an organ of the body politic and serves that body politic.
